revision.comment: Typo/[[WP:AWB/GF|general]] fixing, replaced: referedum → referendum using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
An '''environmental management scheme''' is a mechanism by which landowners and other individuals and bodies responsible for [[land management]] can be incentivised to manage their environment.
==Schemes by country==
===Australia===
Several schemes (prgrammes) are or have been in operation in [[Australia]], including: * [[National Heritage Trust Funds (1 and 2)]] * [[National Action Plan for Salinity]] * [[Caring for Our Country]]
Other programmes exist with the various states, for example; New South Wales - Catchment Action Plan
===United Kingdom===
Several schemes are or have been in operation in the [[United Kingdom]], including: * [[Countryside Stewardship]] * [[Environmental Stewardship]] * [[Environmentally Sensitive Areas Scheme]]
Currently England operates:
* Entry Level Stewardship * Higher Level Stewardship * Organic Entry Level Stewardship * Higher Level Organic Entry Level stewardship
All of these schemes are adminisitered by Natural England
===Scotland===
In 2007 Scotland adopted the SRDP (Scottish Rural Development Programme - a £1.6 billion programme of economic, environmental and social measures designed to develop rural Scotland. Individuals and groups may seek support to help deliver the Government's strategic objectives in rural Scotland.
===Wales===
Until recently the prevailing agri-environment scheme in Wales was Tir Gofal, which means literally ‘Land Care’. It was the first scheme in Wales, and indeed in Europe, aimed at promoting whole farm conservation and management. It was different from previous schemes, as it brought farming and conservation into a different level of partnership.
It was recently announced that this scheme has ceased, with a bridging payment scheme until its replacement is launched.
===France===
In some countries such as [[France]], such schemes may be initiated by the central government: * [[Schéma directeur d'aménagement et de gestion des eaux]]
===Switzerland===
Switzerland started reforming its agricultural policies in 1993 and after a referendum in 1996, since 1998 the country has linked the attribution of farm subsidies with the strict observance of good environmental practice. Before farmers can apply for subsidies, they must obtain certificates of environmental management systems (EMS) proving that they: “make a balanced use of fertilizers; use at least 7% of their farmland as ecological compensation areas; regularly rotate crops; adopt appropriate measures to protect animals and soil; make limited and targeted use of pesticides.”<ref name = bsf>[http://www.bfs.admin.ch/bfs/portal/en/index/themen/02/22/publ.Document.77351.pdf Swiss Environmental Statistics Office.]</ref>
== See also == * [[Environmental management]]
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Environmental management schemes| ]]
{{Environment-stub}}

:A.{{Note|A}} Height above sea level is the usual choice of definition for elevation. In terms of the point farthest away from the centre of the Earth, [[Chimborazo (volcano)|Chimborazo]] in [[Ecuador]] ({{convert|6267|m|abbr=in|0}}) can be considered the planet's most extreme high point. This is due to the Earth's [[oblate spheroid]] shape, with points near the [[Equator]] being farther out from the centre than those at the poles. :B.{{Note|B}} All temperatures from the [[World Meteorological Organization]] unless noted. :C.{{Note|C}} The former record of {{Convert|57.7|C}} recorded at [[Al 'Aziziyah]], [[Libya]] on 13 September 1922 was ruled no longer valid by the WMO due to mistakes made in the recording process.{{cite web|author=PWMU |url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/mediacentre/press_releases/pr_956_en.html |title=Ninety-year-old World temperature record in El Azizia (Libya) is invalid Improved data strengthens Climate knowledge |publisher=Wmo.int |date= |accessdate=2013-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160406053728/http://www.wmo.int/pages/mediacentre/press_releases/pr_956_en.html |archivedate=2016-04-06 |df= }} The 1913 reading is, however, [[List of weather records#Highest temperatures ever recorded|itself controversial]], and a measurement of {{Convert|54.0|C}} at Furnace Creek on 30 June 2013 is undisputed, especially since the same or almost the same temperature has been recorded several times in the 21st century in the same and other places. :E.{{Note|E}} Temperatures greater than {{convert|50|C}} in Spain and [[Portugal]] were recorded in 1881, but the standard with which they were measured and the accuracy of the thermometers used are unknown; therefore, they are not considered official. Unconfirmed reports also indicate that a set of Spanish stations may have hit {{convert|48.0|C}} during the [[2003 European heat wave|2003 heat wave]].[http://wmo.asu.edu/europe-highest-temperature Europe: Highest Temperature] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090629061515/http://wmo.asu.edu/europe-highest-temperature |date=June 29, 2009 }} WMO :F.{{Note|F}} A temperature of {{Convert|−66.1|C}} was recorded at [[North Ice]], [[Greenland]] on 9 January 1954. However due to unknown recording conditions it is not considered official.{{cite web|url=http://wmo.asu.edu/western-hemisphere-lowest-temperature |title=Western Hemisphere: Lowest Temperature |publisher=Wmo.asu.edu |date=1954-01-09 |accessdate=2013-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130518042137/http://wmo.asu.edu/western-hemisphere-lowest-temperature |archivedate=2013-05-18 |df= }} :G.{{Note|G}} A temperature of {{convert|53.1|C}} was recorded in [[Cloncurry, Queensland|Cloncurry]], [[Queensland]] on 16 January 1889 under non-standard exposure conditions and is therefore not considered official.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2003/s1015670.htm |title=Transcript of report on the highest temperature |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2003-12-24 |accessdate=2013-06-25}} :H.{{Note|H}} A temperature of {{Convert|−25.6|C}} is reported for [[Ranfurly, New Zealand|Ranfurly]], New Zealand having occurred on 18 July 1903. However, it is not listed by the WMO.{{cite web|url=http://www.niwa.co.nz/news/new-zealand%E2%80%99s-coldest-recorded-temperature-0 |title=New Zealand’s coldest recorded temperature |publisher=Niwa.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2013-06-25}}
|} ==Temperature Extremes By Month== {{Weather box |location = the World (both hemispheres) |metric first = yes |single line = yes |Jan record high C = 50.7 |Feb record high C = 50.5 |Mar record high C = 47.8 |Apr record high C = 50.2 |May record high C = 53.5 |Jun record high C = 54.0 |Jul record high C = 56.7 |Aug record high C = 53.9 |Sep record high C = 57.8 |Oct record high C = 48.8 |Nov record high C = 48.7 |Dec record high C = 49.5 |year record high C = |Jan record low C = -71.2 |Feb record low C = -67.8 |Mar record low C = -75.5 |Apr record low C = -86.0 |May record low C = -81.2 |Jun record low C = -86.1 |Jul record low C = -89.2 |Aug record low C = -93.2 |Sep record low C = -85.9 |Oct record low C = -80.0 |Nov record low C = -66.1 |Dec record low C = -64.5 |year record low C = ||date=December 2018}} ==Coldest and hottest inhabited places on Earth== {| class="wikitable" | Hottest inhabited place || [[Dallol, Ethiopia]] (Amharic: ዳሎል), whose annual mean temperature was recorded from 1960 to 1966 as {{convert|34.4|C}}.p. 9, ''Weather Experiments'', Muriel Mandell and Dave Garbot, Sterling Publishing Company, Inc., 2006, {{ISBN|1-4027-2157-9}}. The average daily maximum temperature during the same period was {{convert|41.1|C}}.Average of table on p. 26, ''Extreme Weather: A Guide & Record Book'', Christopher C. Burt and Mark Stroud, New York: W. W. Norton & Company, 2007, {{ISBN|0-393-33015-X}}. |- | rowspan=2|Coldest inhabited place ||[[Delyankir]] (Russian: Делянкир), a rural locality (selo) in Oymyakonsky District of the [[Sakha Republic]], the Russian Federation, has the coldest monthly mean, with {{convert|-51|C|F}} the average temperature in January, the coldest month.{{Cite web|url=https://www.weather-atlas.com/en/russia/delyankir-climate|title=Delyankir, Russia - Detailed climate information and monthly weather forecast {{!}} Weather Atlas|last=d.o.o.|first=Yu Media Group|website=Weather Atlas|language=en|access-date=2018-11-20}} [[Eureka, Nunavut|Eureka]], Nunavut, Canada has the lowest annual mean temperature at {{convert|-19.7|C}}.{{cite web|url=http://climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca/climate_normals/results_e.html?stnID=1750&lang=e&dCode=1&StationName=EUREKA&SearchType=Contains&province=ALL&provBut=&month1=0&month2=12 |title=Canadian Climate Normals 1971-2000 |publisher=Climate.weatheroffice.gc.ca |date=2013-02-04 |accessdate=2013-06-25}} |- |The [[South Pole]] and some other places in [[Antarctica]] are colder and are populated year-round, but almost everyone stays less than a year and could be considered visitors, not inhabitants. |} ==Extreme ground temperatures== Temperatures measured directly on the ground may exceed air temperatures by 30 to 50 °C.p. 855-857, [http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/2011BAMS3067.1 Satellite Finds Highest Land Skin Temperatures on Earth], David J. Mildrexler, Maosheng Zhao, and Steven W. Running, ''Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society'', July 2011, pp. 855-860, {{doi|10.1175/2011BAMS3067.1}}. A ground temperature of 84 °C (183.2 °F) has been recorded in [[Port Sudan]], [[Sudan]].Table 9.2, p. 158, ''Dryland Climatology'', Sharon E. Nicholson, Cambridge University Press, 2011, {{ISBN|1139500244}}. A ground temperature of 93.9 °C (201 °F) was recorded in [[Furnace Creek, California|Furnace Creek]], [[Death Valley]], [[California]], United States on 15 July 1972; this may be the highest natural ground surface temperature ever recorded.A possible world record maximum natural ground surface temperature, Paul Kubecka, ''Weather'', '''56''', #7 (July 2001), ''Weather'', pp. 218-221, {{doi|10.1002/j.1477-8696.2001.tb06577.x}}. The theoretical maximum possible ground surface temperature has been estimated to be between 90 and 100 °C for dry, darkish soils of low thermal conductivity.[http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0450%281992%29031%3C1096%3AEMLST%3E2.0.CO%3B2 Extreme Maximum Land Surface Temperatures], J. R. Garratt, Journal of Applied Meteorology, '''31''', #9 (September 1992), pp. 1096–1105, {{doi|10.1175/1520-0450(1992)031<1096:EMLST>2.0.CO;2}}. Satellite measurements of ground temperature taken between 2003 and 2009, taken with the [[MODIS]] [[infrared]] spectroradiometer on the [[Aqua (satellite)|Aqua]] satellite, found a maximum temperature of 70.7 °C (159.3 °F), which was recorded in 2005 in the [[Lut Desert]], [[Iran]]. The Lut Desert was also found to have the highest maximum temperature in 5 of the 7 years measured (2004, 2005, 2006, 2007 and 2009). These measurements reflect averages over a large region and so are lower than the maximum point surface temperature. Satellite measurements of the surface temperature of Antarctica, taken between 1982 and 2013, found a coldest temperature of −93.2 °C (−136 °F) on 10 August 2010, at {{Coord|81.8|S|59.3|E}}. Although this is not comparable to an air temperature, it is believed that the air temperature at this location would have been lower than the official record lowest air temperature of −89.2 °C.[https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-25287806 Coldest spot on Earth identified by satellite], Jonathan Amos, BBC News, 9 December 2013.[http://fallmeeting.agu.org/2013/files/2013/12/ColdestPlaceOnEarth.pdf The Coldest Place on Earth: -90°C and below from Landsat 8 and other satellite thermal sensors], Ted Scambos, Allen Pope, Garrett Campbell, and Terry Haran, [[American Geophysical Union]] fall meeting, 9 December 2013. ==Greatest vertical drop== {| class="wikitable" | Greatest purely vertical drop || [[Image:Mount Thor Peak 1997-08-07.jpg|right|100px]]{{convert|1250|m|abbr=on|0}}

Various shifting [[gravel bar]]s lie further north, the most famous being [[Oodaaq]] |- | Southernmost point on land || [[South Pole#Geography|The geographic South Pole]] |- | Southernmost continental point of land outside Antarctica|| [[Cape Froward]] ({{Lang-es|Cabo Froward}}) ({{Coord|53|56|00|S|071|20|00|W|display=inline}}), [[Magallanes Region]], [[Chile]] |} The [[Gould Coast]] (Coordinates: {{coord|84|30|S|150|0|W}}){{cite web|title=Antarctica Detail|url=http://geonames.usgs.gov/apex/f?p=gnispq:5:0::NO::P5_ANTAR_ID:5881|website=geonames.usgs.gov}} US Geographic Survey. is the southernmost point of ocean while the southernmost [[open sea]] is nearby [[Bay of Whales]] at 78°30'S, at the edge of [[Ross Ice Shelf]].{{cite web|title=Bay of Whales {{!}} former bay, Antarctica|url=http://www.britannica.com/place/Bay-of-Whales|website=[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]}} ==See also== {{Portal|Earth sciences}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Extreme points of Earth]] * [[List of Solar System extremes]] * [[List of extrasolar planet extremes]] * [[List of northernmost items]] * [[List of southernmost items]] * [[List of weather records]] * [[Northernmost settlements]] * [[Southernmost settlements]] {{div col end}} ==References== World Meteorological Organisation. {{Taxation}} A '''fuel tax''' (also known as a '''petrol''', '''gasoline''' or '''gas tax''', or as a '''fuel duty''') is an [[excise tax]] imposed on the sale of [[fuel]]. In most countries the fuel tax is imposed on fuels which are intended for transportation. Fuels used to power agricultural vehicles, and/or home [[heating oil]] which is similar to [[diesel fuel|diesel]] are taxed at a different, usually lower rate. The fuel tax receipts are often dedicated or [[hypothecation (taxation)|hypothecated]] to transportation projects so that the fuel tax is considered by many a [[user fee]]. In other countries, the fuel tax is a source of general revenue. Sometimes, the fuel tax is used as an [[ecotax]], to promote ecological sustainability. Fuel taxes are often considered {{By whom|date=October 2017}} [[regressive tax]]es.<ref>https://apps.irs.gov/app/understandingTaxes/whys/thm03/les05/media/ws_ans_thm03_les05.pdf</ref>
==Role in energy policy==
Taxes on [[transportation]] fuels have been advocated as a way to reduce pollution and the possibility of [[global warming]] and conserve energy. Placing higher taxes on fossil fuels makes petrol just as expensive as other fuels such as natural gas, [[biodiesel]] or electric batteries, at a cost to the consumer in the form of inflation as transportation costs rise to transport goods all over the country.
Proponents advocate that automobiles should pay for the roads they use and argue that the user tax should not be applied to mass transit projects.
The [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]], the [[International Energy Agency]], the [[International Monetary Fund]], and the [[World Bank]] have called on governments to increase gasoline tax rates in order to combat the social and environmental costs of gasoline consumption.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Ross|first=Michael L.|last2=Hazlett|first2=Chad|last3=Mahdavi|first3=Paasha|title=Global progress and backsliding on gasoline taxes and subsidies|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nenergy2016201|journal=Nature Energy|volume=2|issue=1|doi=10.1038/nenergy.2016.201|bibcode=2017NatEn...216201R}}</ref>
==Tax rates== {{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=January 2010}} International pump prices for diesel and gasoline for November 2010 are available at https://web.archive.org/web/20110315151539/http://www.gtz.de/en/themen/29957.htm . Price history from surveys taken in November of even number years are also available. Price differences mostly reflect differences in tax policy.
A Nature study has shown that while gasoline taxes have increased in more countries than they have decreased in during the period 2003-2015, the global mean gasoline tax has decreased due to greater consumption in the low tax countries.<ref name=":0" /> [[File:Fuel tax in OECD countries, 2010..png|thumb|Fuel tax in OECD countries 2010 <ref>Petrol tax, The Economist, 25 Sep 2010, p. 110</ref>]]
===Asia=== . ====China==== Chinese gasoline taxes have increased the most among the top twenty CO2-emitting countries over the period 2003-2015.<ref name=":0" />
In [[China]], fuel tax has been a very contentious issue. Efforts by the [[State Council of the People's Republic of China|State Council]] to institute a fuel tax in order to finance the [[National Trunk Highway System]] have run into strong opposition from the [[National People's Congress]], largely out of concern for its impact on farmers. This has been one of the uncommon instances in which the legislature has asserted its authority.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rsc.org/chemistryworld/Issues/2009/January/ChinaBitesTheBulletOnFuelTax.asp |first=Hepeng |last=Jia |date=8 January 2009 |title=China bites the bullet on fuel tax |publisher=Chemistry World |accessdate=30 December 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161230063848/https://www.chemistryworld.com/news/china-bites-the-bullet-on-fuel-tax/1014042.article |archivedate=30 December 2016 |deadurl=no |df= }} </ref>
==== Hong Kong ==== In [[Hong Kong]], leaded petrol is taxed at [[Hong Kong dollar|HK$]]6.82 per litre and unleaded petrol at HK$6.06 per litre. The tax on Euro V diesel is $0.<ref> {{cite web |url=http://www.customs.gov.hk/en/trade_facilitation/dutiable/types/#hydrocarbon_oil |title=Types and Duty Rates |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161021014512/http://www.customs.gov.hk/en/trade_facilitation/dutiable/types/ |archivedate=21 October 2016 |publisher=Customs and Excise Department, The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region |deadurl=yes |df= }} </ref> <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201411/20/P201411200494.htm |title=LCQ3: Retail prices of auto-fuels |date=20 November 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304112442/http://www.info.gov.hk/gia/general/201411/20/P201411200494.htm |archivedate=4 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }} </ref>
====India==== In [[India]], the pricing of fuel varies by state, though central taxes still are part of the pump price of fuel. The Central and state government's taxes make up nearly half of petrol's pump price. The Central govt has different taxes, which amount to about 24–26% of the final cost. The states taxes vary, but on average end up making about 20–25% of the final cost. As a result, approximately 51% of the pump cost goes to the government in the form of different taxes.
For example, in [[Bangalore|Bengaluru]], [[Karnataka]] as of May 16, 2011, price of petrol is {{INRConvert|71.09}} per litre. Out of this, {{INRConvert|17.06}} go to [[Govt of India]] in the form of excise and customs tax. {{INRConvert|16.63}} is collected by [[Government of Karnataka|state government]] in the form of sales tax and entry tax. Thus, a total of {{INRConvert|33.69}} is collected due to various taxes (which accounts for around 47% of the total price).<ref name="Half of what you pay for petrol is taxes"> {{cite news |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/161967/half-you-pay-petrol-taxes.html |title=Half of what you pay for petrol is taxes |work=Deccan Herald |date=May 16, 2011 |accessdate=May 25, 2012 |first=Shamsheer |last=Yousaf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304073348/http://www.deccanherald.com/content/161967/half-you-pay-petrol-taxes.html |archivedate=4 March 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Europe===
====France==== Petroleum products destined for utilisation by aircraft engaged in commercial flights outside of the customs territory of continental France are exempt from all customs duties and domestic taxes.<ref>France Customs Code (Code des Douanes) Article 195</ref>
====Germany==== Fuel taxes in Germany are €0.4704 per litre for ultra-low sulphur Diesel and €0.6545 per litre for conventional unleaded petrol, plus Value Added Tax (19%) on the fuel itself and the Fuel Tax. That adds up to prices of €1.12 per litre for ultra-low sulphur Diesel and €1.27 per litre (approximately US$6.14 per US gallon) for unleaded petrol (December 2014).
====Netherlands==== The sale of fuels in the [[Netherlands]] is levied with an [[excise tax]]. As of 2015, petrol excise tax is EUR0.766 per litre and diesel excise tax is EUR0.482 per litre, while LPG excise tax is EUR0.185 per litre.<ref> {{cite web |title=PETROL, DIESEL TAX TO RISE 1 PCT; LPG TAX ALSO UP |first=Janene |last=Pieters |date=12 December 2014 |work=nltimes.nl |url=http://www.nltimes.nl/2014/12/12/petrol-diesel-tax-rise-1-pct-lpg-tax-also |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109143143/http://www.nltimes.nl/2014/12/12/petrol-diesel-tax-rise-1-pct-lpg-tax-also/ |archivedate=9 January 2016 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The 2007 fuel tax was €0.684 per litre or $3.5 per gallon. On top of that is 21% VAT over the entire fuel price, making the Dutch taxes one of the highest in the world. In total, taxes account for 68.84% of the total price of petrol and 56.55% of the total price of diesel.<ref>[http://www.minfin.nl/Onderwerpen/Belastingen/Kostprijsverhogende_belastingen/Accijnzen_en_verbruiksbelastingen/Feiten_over_belasting_op_brandstof#internelink2 ]{{dead link|date=February 2010}}</ref> A 1995 excise was raised by [[Dutch gulden]] 25 cents (€0.11), the ''Kok Quarter'' (€0.08 raise per litre [[gasoline]] and €0.03 raise per litre [[diesel fuel|diesel]]), by then Prime-Minister [[Wim Kok]] is now specifically set aside by the [[second Balkenende cabinet]] for use in road creation and road and public transport maintenance.
====Norway==== Motor fuel is taxed with both a ''road use tax'' and a ''CO<sub>2</sub>-tax''. The road use tax on petrol is [[Norwegian krone|NOK]] 4.62 per litre and the CO<sub>2</sub>-tax on petrol is NOK 0.88 per litre. The road use tax on auto diesel is NOK 3.62 per litre mineral oil and NOK 1.81 per litre bio diesel. The CO<sub>2</sub>-tax on mineral oil is NOK 0.59 per litre.<ref>[http://www.statsbudsjettet.no/Statsbudsjettet-2011/English/?pid=48921#hopp Main features of the Government’s tax programme for 2011]</ref>
====Poland==== In [[Poland]] half of the end-user price charged at a petrol station goes towards 3 distinct taxes: * akcyza (meaning [[excise]]) * opłata paliwowa (meaning fuel tax) * Value-added tax "[[VAT]]" at 23% (from summary of akcyza and opłata paliwowa, and the price of petrol) Excise and fuel tax are prescribed by [[European Union|European Commission law]], and therefore cannot be lower in any [[European Union|EU]] nation. However it is even higher than this EU minimum in Poland, a policy pursued by the former [[Jan Vincent-Rostowski|Minister of finance]]. <ref>http://biznes.gazetaprawna.pl/artykuly/535404,mamy_najdrozsze_paliwo_na_swiecie_polowa_ceny_to_podatki.html</ref>
====Russia==== Tax on mineral resource extraction (2008–2009): *Oil: varies 1000 RUR/t – 13800 RUR/t; middle MRET 3000 RUR/t (0.058 €/l = 0.284 $/gal). *Natural gas: 147 RUR/1000m³ (4 €/1000m³). *Petroleum gas: no
Excise tax on motor fuel 2008–2009: *RON >80: 3629 RUR/t. (0.071 €/l = 0.343 $/US gal) *RON <=80: 2657 RUR/t. (0.052 €/l = 0.251 $/US
Other fuel (like avia gasoline, jet fuel, heavy oils, natural gas and autogas) prices has no excise tax.
Value Added Tax — 18% on fuel and taxes.
Full tax rate is near 55% of motor fuel prices (ministry of industry and energy facts 2006).
====Sweden==== The fuel tax in Sweden comprises a [[carbon tax]] and an [[energy tax]]. The total tax (including [[value added tax]]) is, from July 1, 2018, {{SEK|8.425}} per liter petrol and {{SEK|7.425}} per liter diesel.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://skatteverket.se/foretagochorganisationer/skatter/punktskatter/energiskatter/skattesatserochvaxelkurser.4.77dbcb041438070e0395e96.html|title=Skattesatser på bränslen och el under 2016|website=skatteverket.se|language=sv|access-date=2018-08-16}}</ref>
====United Kingdom==== {{Main|Hydrocarbon oil duty}} From 23 March 2011 the UK duty rate for the road fuels unleaded petrol, diesel, biodiesel and bioethanol is {{GBP|0.5795}} per litre (£2.63 per imperial gallon or £2.19 per U.S. gallon).<ref name=hmrc>{{cite web|url=http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/budget2011/tiin6330.pdf|title=Hydrocarbon Oils: Duty Rates|publisher=HMRC|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523135710/http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/budget2011/tiin6330.pdf|archivedate=2011-05-23|df=}}</ref>
[[Value Added Tax]] at 20% is also charged on the price of the fuel and on the duty. An additional [[vehicle excise duty]], depending on a vehicle's theoretical CO2 production per kilometre, which is applied regardless of the amount of fuel actually consumed, is also levied.
Diesel for use by farmers and construction vehicles is coloured red (Red Diesel) and has a much reduced tax, currently {{GBP|0.1133}} per litre (£0.52 per imperial gallon or £0.43 per U.S. gallon).<ref name=hmrc/>
Jet fuel used for international aviation attracts no duty, and no VAT.<ref>{{cite web|title=Notice 179A Aviation Turbine Fuel (Avtur)|publisher=HM Revenue & Customs|date=December 2006|url=http://customs.hmrc.gov.uk/channelsPortalWebApp/downloadFile?contentID=HMCE_CL_000186}}</ref>
===North America===
====Canada==== {{Main|Motor fuel taxes in Canada}}
[[Fuel taxes in Canada]] can vary greatly between locales. On average, about one-third of the total price of gas at the pump is tax. [[Excise tax]]es on [[gasoline]] and [[diesel fuel|diesel]] are collected both federal and provincial governments, as well as by some select municipalities ([[Montreal]], [[Vancouver]], and [[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]]); with combined excise taxes varying from 16.2 ¢/L (73.6 ¢/imperial gal; 61.2 ¢/US gal) in the [[Yukon]] to 30.5 ¢/L ($1.386/imperial gal; $1.552/?US gal) in [[Vancouver]]. As well, the federal government and some provincial governments ([[Newfoundland and Labrador]], [[Nova Scotia]], and [[Quebec]]) collect [[sales tax]] ([[Sales taxes in Canada|GST and PST]]) on top of the retail price ''and'' the excise taxes.<ref>{{cite news | first= | last= | coauthors= | title=Oil and Gas Prices, Taxes and Consumers | date=July 2006 | publisher=Department of Finance (Canada) | url =http://www.fin.gc.ca/toce/2006/gas_tax-e.html | work = | pages =6b) Application of the GST | accessdate = 2007-12-13 | language = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071221030022/http://www.fin.gc.ca/toce/2006/gas_tax-e.html |archivedate = December 21, 2007|deadurl=yes}}</ref>
====United States====
{{Main|Fuel taxes in the United States}}
The first U.S. state to enact a gas tax was [[Oregon]] in 1919.<ref>{{cite journal| last1=Ball & Moran| title=Penny Lane, Literally: Funding Roads One Vehicle Mile at a Time| journal=Willamette Environmental Law Journal| date=2016| volume=5| page=1| url=https://willamette.edu/law/resources/journals/welj/pdf/2016/2016-f-welj-moran.pdf}}</ref> The states of [[Colorado]], [[North Dakota]], and [[New Mexico]] followed shortly thereafter. By 1929, all existing 48 states had enacted some sort of gas tax.<ref name="Pain at the Pump">"Pain at the Pump", Rall, Jamie. State Legislatures magazine; June 2013. National Conference of State Legislatures</ref> Today, fuel taxes in the United States vary by state. The United States federal [[excise tax]] on gasoline is 18.4 cents per gallon (4.86 ¢/L) and 24.4 cents per gallon (6.45 ¢/L) for [[diesel fuel]]. On average, as of July 2016, state and local taxes add 29.78 cents to gasoline and 29.81 cents to diesel for a total US average fuel tax of 48.18 cents per gallon for gas (12.89 ¢/L) and 54.21 cents per gallon for diesel (14.37 ¢/L).<ref name="Motor Fuel Taxes: State Gasoline Tax Reports">{{cite web|url=http://www.api.org/oil-and-natural-gas/consumer-information/motor-fuel-taxes|title=Motor Fuel Taxes: State Gasoline Tax Reports|date=|year=2016|publisher=API}}</ref>
The state and local tax figures includes fixed-per-gallon taxes as well as variable-rate taxes such as those levied as a percentage of the sales price. For state-level fuel taxes, nineteen states and the District of Columbia levy variable-rate taxes of some kind.<ref name="Most Americans Live in States with Variable-Rate Gas Taxes">{{cite web|url=http://itep.org/itep_reports/2016/02/most-americans-live-in-states-with-variable-rate-gas-taxes-2.php|title=Most Americans Live in States with Variable-Rate Gas Taxes|date=|year=2016|publisher=ITEP}}</ref> The other thirty one states do not tie the per-gallon tax rate to inflation, gas prices, or other factors, and the rate changes only by legislation. As of July 2016, twenty one states had gone ten years or more without an increase in their per-gallon gasoline tax rate.<ref name="How Long Has It Been Since Your State Raised Its Gas Tax?">{{cite web|url=http://itep.org/itep_reports/2016/06/how-long-has-it-been-since-your-state-raised-its-gas-tax-1.php|title=How Long Has It Been Since Your State Raised Its Gas Tax?|date=|year=2016|publisher=ITEP}}</ref>
Because the fuel tax is universally styled as a "road use" tax, exempting off-road farming, marine, etc. use; states impose a tax on commercial operators traveling through their state as if the fuel used was bought there, wherever the fuel is purchased. While most commercial truck drivers have an agent to handle the required paperwork: what's reported is how much tax was collected in each state, how much should have been paid to each state, the net tax for each state and the combined net tax for all states to be paid by or refunded to the operator by their base jurisdiction where they file. The operator carries paperwork proving compliance. The member jurisdictions, the US states and the CA provinces, transmit the return information to each other and settle their net tax balances with each other either by a single transmittal through a clearinghouse set up by the IFTA and operated by Morgan Stanley, or by separate transfers with the other member jurisdictions.<ref name="IFTA">[http://www.iftach.org International Fuel Tax Agreement<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
===Oceania===
====Australia==== The [[Fuel taxes in Australia|fuel tax system in Australia]] is very similar to [[Canada]] in terms of featuring both a fixed and a variable tax, but varies in the case of exemptions including [[tax credits]] and certain excise free fuel.
Since October 2018, the fuel tax in Australia is A$0.412 per litre for petrol and ultra-low sulphur diesel (conventional diesel being taxed at A$0.412 per litre) and the excise for LPG is $0.282 per litre. Since 2000, there is also the GST (goods and services tax) on top of the fuel tax and inflation calculated twice a year called CPI (consumer price index) into the fuel tax since 2015.<ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fuel_taxes_in_Australia]</ref><ref>[https://www.ato.gov.au/business/excise-and-excise-equivalent-goods/fuel-excise/excise-rates-for-fuel/]</ref>
====New Zealand==== Fuel taxes in [[New Zealand]] are considered an [[excise]] applied by the [[New Zealand Customs Service]] on shipments brought into the country. A breakdown of the fuel taxes is published by the [http://www.med.govt.nz/templates/Page____12961.aspx Ministry of Economic Development]. Excise as at 1 August 2012 totals 50.524 cents per litre ($1.89/imperial gal; $1.58/US gal) on petrol. In addition the national compulsory [https://web.archive.org/web/20100602001025/http://www.acc.co.nz/news/PRD_CTRB091172 Accident Compensation Corporation] motor vehicle account receives a contribution of 9.9 cents/litre (37.1¢/imperial gal; 30.9¢/US gal). The ethanol component of bio blended petrol currently attracts no excise duty. This was to be reviewed in 2012. Diesel is not taxed at the pump, but road users with vehicles over 3.5 tonne in Gross Laden Weight and any vehicles not powered wholly by any combination of petrol, LPG or CNG must pay the [http://www.landtransport.govt.nz/commercial/ruc.html Road User Charge] instead. The [[Goods and Services Tax (New Zealand)|Goods and Services Tax]] (15%) is then applied to the combined total of the value of the commodity and the various taxes. On 25 July 2007 the Minister of Transport Annette King announced that from 1 July 2008 all fuel excise collected would be hypothecated to the National Land Transport Programme.<ref>{{cite news| first=| last=| coauthors=| title=Fuel excise duty revenue will all be used on land transport| date=July 2007| publisher=Beehive (New Zealand)| url=http://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/fuel+excise+duty+revenue+will+all+be+used+land+transport| work=| pages=| accessdate=2008-01-17| language=| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080318175931/http://www.beehive.govt.nz/release/fuel+excise+duty+revenue+will+all+be+used+land+transport| archivedate=2008-03-18| df=}}</ref>
===Africa===
====South Africa==== Diesel tax - for road use ( $ per gallon ): $1.46. Gasoline tax - for road use ( $ per gallon ): $1.58.
==See also== * [[Carbon tax]] * [[Oil price increases since 2003#Fuel taxes|Fuel taxes and rising oil prices]] – how the taxes of various countries could be used to mitigate the rise in oil prices since 2003 * [[Excise tax]] * [[Vehicle miles traveled tax]] * [[International Fuel Tax Agreement]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.gtz.de/de/dokumente/gtz2009-en-ifp-full-version.pdf International Fuel Prices 2009] with diesel and gasoline prices of 172 countries and information on fuel taxation for state financing * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120207151531/http://www.nacsonline.com/NACS/Resources/campaigns/GasPrices_2012/Pages/default.aspx 2012 NACS Retail Fuels Report] * [http://www.energy.eu/#fueltaxes Actual taxes on Unleaded and diesel Fuels in Europe]
[[Category:Fuel taxes| ]] [[Category:Ecotax]] [[Category:Petroleum products]] [[Category:Energy economics]] [[Category:Transport economics]] [[Category:Vehicle taxes]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} [[File:Doman LZ-5.jpg|thumb|Glidden Doman with the Doman LZ-5/YH-31 helicopter (1953)|400px]] '''Glidden Doman''' (January 28, 1921 – June 6, 2016) was an American aeronautical engineer and pioneer in helicopters and modern wind turbines.<ref name="one">{{cite web|last1=de Vries|first1=Eize|title=Two blades – Condor Wind's 5MW offshore turbine|url=http://www.windpowermonthly.com/article/1073749/two-blades---condor-winds-5mw-offshore-turbine|website=Wndpower Monthly|publisher=Windpower Offshore|accessdate=June 7, 2011}}</ref> He founded one of America's original six helicopter companies (Doman Helicopters, Inc.) after making major contributions to the use of [[Sikorsky Aircraft|Sikorsky]] helicopters during World War II.<ref name="two">{{cite journal|last1=Doman|first1=Steve|title=Glidden Doman's Rotor Technology for Helicopters and Wind Turbines – A 65 Year History|journal=The EPCo Group|date=August 2, 2011}}</ref> Doman Helicopters' most prominent achievement was the [[Doman LZ-5]]/YH-31 eight-place helicopter, which received [[FAA]] certification on December 30, 1955.<ref name="three">{{cite web|last1=Gibbon|first1=Terry|title=Doman Helicopters, Inc.|url=http://www.theepcogroup.com/doman-helicopters.html|website=The EPCo Group|accessdate=February 21, 2009}}</ref> The unique feature of this helicopter was its hinge-less but gimbaled, tilting rotor hub that greatly reduced stress and vibration in the blades and in the whole helicopter.<ref name="four">{{cite web|title=AHS Mourns the Loss of Glid Doman, Last Helicopter Pioneer|url=https://vtol.org/news/ahs-mourns-the-loss-of-glid-doman-last-helicopter-pioneer|website=American Helicopter Society|publisher=AHS International|accessdate=June 7, 2016}}</ref>
Doman was one of the first to transfer knowledge of [[helicopter rotor]] dynamics technology to wind turbines.<ref name="five">{{cite web|last1=Stempien|first1=Alexis|title=Mourning the loss of alumnus Glidden Doman|url=http://www.engin.umich.edu/college/about/news/stories/2016/june/mourning-the-loss-of-alumnus-glidden-doman|website=University of Michigan – Michigan Engineering|publisher=University of Michigan|accessdate=June 10, 2016}}</ref> The [[1973 arab oil embargo]] prompted [[NASA Glenn Research Center]] in Cleveland, Ohio to lead a 7-year US wind energy program for the development of utility-scale horizontal axis wind turbines.<ref name="six">{{cite web|last1=Bowles|first1=Mark D.|title=The Apollo of Aeronautics NASA's Aircraft Energy Efiiciency Program|url=https://www.nasa.gov/connect/ebooks/aero_apollo_detail.html|website=NASA|publisher=NASA|accessdate=September 7, 2012}}</ref> This program featured the creation of Boeing's MOD-2 with the Doman conceived flexible rotor design, two-bladed wind turbine with a teeter hinge.<ref name="seven">{{cite web|title=Wind Energy Research Reaps Rewards|url=https://www.nasa.gov/vision/earth/technologies/wind_turbines.html|website=NASA|accessdate=May 31, 2006}}</ref> Following the [[NASA]] project, while working for [[Boeing]], [[Hamilton Standard]] division of [[United Technologies]], and [[Aeritalia]] (later known as [[Alenia Aeronautica|Alenia]]) in Italy, Doman developed large two-bladed, teeter-hinged wind turbines, including the WTS-3, WTS-4, and the Gamma 60.<ref name=seven /><ref name="eight">{{cite web|last1=Jakubowski|first1=Martin|title=History of the Development of the Seawind Technology|url=http://seawindtechnology.com/history/|website=Seawind Technology|publisher=Seawind Ocean Technology|accessdate=January 7, 2017}}</ref> After testing the Gamma 60 in Sardinia for 7 years, Doman and Italian nuclear mechanical engineer Silvestro Caruso founded Gamma Ventures, Inc. to further develop and market this technology.<ref name=one /><ref name=eight /> Gamma Ventures subsequently invested in, and sold a license to Seawind of the Netherlands, to commercialize the same two-bladed, teeter-hinge wind turbine concept.<ref name=two /><ref name=eight />
Doman, along with noted German-born aerospace engineer [[Kurt Hohenemser]] (a partner and confidant of the well-known German airplane and helicopter designer [[Anton Flettner]]), maintained that a flexible two-bladed helicopter type wind turbine rotor design that is compliant with the forces of nature was more suitable for producing electricity than the rigid industry standard three-bladed airplane type wind turbine rotors that, by design, can only be constructed to resist the forces of nature.<ref name="nine">{{cite book|last1=Spera|first1=David A.|title=Wind Turbine Technology: Fundamental Concepts of Wind Turbine Engineering|date=2009|publisher=ASME Press|pages=Chapter 10|ref=Wind Turbine Engineering System Designs}}</ref><ref name="ten">{{cite web|last1=Martin|first1=Douglas|title=Kurt Hohenemser, Early Helicopter Designer, Dies at 95|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/04/21/us/kurt-hohenemser-early-helicopter-designer-dies-at-95.html|website=New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=April 21, 2001}}</ref><ref name="eleven">{{cite journal|title=Anton Flettner|journal=The New York Times|date=December 30, 1961|volume=Obituary}}</ref><ref name="twelve">{{cite journal|last1=Hohenemser|first1=Kurt H.|title=Letter to Mr. Raven – The Great Nephew of Anton Flettner|date=September 30, 2001}}</ref>
Two of Doman's helicopters, the converted Sikorsky R-6 (Doman LZ-1A) and a [[Doman LZ-5]]/YH-31, are on display at the New England Air Museum in Windsor Locks, Connecticut.<ref name="thirteen">{{cite web|last1=Orred|first1=Susan R.|title=Local Granby Resident Glidden S. Doman To Be Featured Guest at New England Air Museum|url=http://articles.courant.com/2013-03-12/community/hcrs-71898hc-granby-20130306_1_wind-turbines-helicopter-pioneers-first-helicopters|website=Hartford Courant|accessdate=March 12, 2013}}</ref> [[File:Doman LZ-5 (YH-31) Helicopter.jpg|thumb|Doman LZ-5/YH-31 helicopter at the New England Air Museum|300px]]
== Early life ==
Glidden Sweet Doman, the son of Albert E. Doman and Ruth Sweet Doman, was born in Syracuse, New York, on January 28, 1921.<ref name="two" /><ref name="four" /><ref name="fourteen">{{cite web|last1=Orred|first1=Susan R.|title=Local Granby Resident is Pioneer in Helicopter and Wind Turbine Design|url=http://patch.com/connecticut/granby-eastgranby/an--local-granby-resident-is-pioneer-in-helicopter-an96a6cdf30c|website=Granby Patch|accessdate=March 6, 2013}}</ref> Living in the small upstate New York village of Elbridge, Doman came from a family of inventors and entrepreneurs.<ref name="two" /> His father Albert and uncles Lewis and George Doman were the first to provide electricity for Elbridge, in 1890.<ref name="two" /> Doman's elder half-brother, Carl T. Doman, designed air cooled Franklin engines for Franklin automobiles and for aircraft – including for the pioneering [[Sikorsky VS-300]] helicopter.<ref name="fourteen" />
In his teens, Doman built a series of six motorized "go carts", and in 1936, at the age of 15, he built a Soapbox Derby racer, the first to be aerodynamically streamlined.<ref name="two" /><ref name="four" /><ref name="fourteen" /> He won the regional Soapbox Derby race held in Syracuse and placed well in the national championship race in Akron, Ohio. (2)(4) Doman also attempted to build an airplane, completing much of the fuselage, but was never able to obtain an engine for it.<ref name="two" />
In 1938, Doman enrolled at the University of Michigan (Ann Arbor) College of Engineering, where he majored in aeronautical engineering.<ref name="five" /> While at Michigan, Doman joined and later became president of the flying club.<ref name="fourteen" /> Another member of the flying club, Joan Hamilton, Doman's future bride, was the only female member of the club.<ref name="fourteen" /> Hamilton obtained her private's pilot license and later during World War II she was invited by the famous aviatrix [[Jacqueline Cochran|Jackie Cochran]] to join the WASPs (Women Air Force Service Pilots), but she declined the offer.<ref name="fourteen" /> [[File:R-4 AC HNS1 3 300.jpg|thumb|Sikorsky R-4 (August 14, 1944, the world's first large-scale mass produced helicopter)|300px]]
== First employments ==
Doman graduated from Michigan in June 1942, just six months after the bombing of Pearl Harbor.<ref name="two" /> After his graduation, he went to work for the Ranger Aircraft Engine Division of Fairchild Aviation in Long Island, New York.<ref name="two" /> Doman had prior experience working with engine technologies while employed during summer vacations at the Franklin Engine Company (where his brother Carl worked).<ref name="two" /> At Ranger, Doman gained experience in using strain gauges to analyze the vibratory loads on the rotating parts of engines.<ref name="two" />
Carl Doman, who knew [[Igor Sikorsky]] due to the Franklin engine's use in the [[Sikorsky VS-300]], invited Doman to attend a Society of Automotive Engineers meeting in New York.<ref name="fourteen" /> At this event, with Sikorsky as a featured speaker, Doman became interested in the vibratory loads in helicopter rotors.<ref name="two" /> As a new and unrefined invention at that time, helicopters were suffering from rotor blades with a very short fatigue life.<ref name="two" /> In fact, not long after Doman met Sikorsky, a Sikorsky YR-4 had a blade fracture during a delivery flight to the Army, which stimulated Doman's interest all the more.<ref name="two" /><ref name="fourteen" />
In August 1943, Doman married Joan Hamilton and they immediately moved to Stamford, Connecticut where he commuted to and from work for [[Sikorsky Aircraft|Sikorsky]] in Bridgeport, CT.<ref name="fourteen" /> Doman put strain gages all over the rotor system of a Sikorsky YR-4 to locate the weak points.<ref name="two" /><ref name="fourteen" /> He then figured out where and how to change the rotor system to achieve longer blade life.<ref name="two" /> Doman's contributions were so vital that Igor Sikorsky himself appealed to Doman's Draft Board to keep him on the test program instead of sending him into the Army or Navy.<ref name="fourteen" /> Doman discovered that the design of the rotor hub was the real cause of the blade failures.<ref name="fourteen" /> For the duration of World War II, he ran a program to match and balance the blades of all the Sikorsky helicopters before they were delivered.<ref name="fourteen" /> Throughout his tenure at Sikorsky, Doman was continuously learning about rotor dynamics.<ref name="fourteen" />
Doman had one very harrowing experience at Sikorsky when he was flying as a test engineer on a YR-4.<ref name="two" /><ref name="fourteen" /> The pilot had slowed the helicopter to very low speed, and it got into the so-called "vortex ring state" where the blades lose lift and the helicopter thrashes around in an almost uncontrollable fashion.<ref name="two" /> Fatal crashes from such an event have resulted more than once in the history of rotary wing aviation.<ref name="two" /> In this case, however, the pilot somehow got the helicopter flying backwards, which enabled the blades to regain their lifting ability and prevent a crash.<ref name="two" /> While at Sikorsky, Doman got to know [[Igor Sikorsky]], and for years afterwards Doman liked to repeat his favorite quote from [[Igor Sikorsky]], "God takes care of helicopters."<ref name="two" /> [[File:Doman LZ-1A (Sikorsky R-6 Conversion).jpg|thumb|Doman LZ-1A (Sikorsky R-6 conversion)|300px]]
== The Doman Helicopter company ==
Together with Clinton Frazier, a mathematician and colleague at [[Sikorsky Aircraft|Sikorsky]], Doman left Sikorsky after WW II to further develop and implement his ideas.<ref name="two" /> Doman-Frazier Helicopters, Inc. was established in the autumn of 1945.<ref name="fourteen" /> The company was initially located in the back of a law office in New York City, but soon moved into a barn in Stratford, Connecticut, not far from the Sikorsky plant.<ref name="fourteen" /> With financial assistance from the [[United States Army Air Corps]], Doman obtained a war surplus R-6 Sikorsky helicopter.<ref name="fifteen">{{cite web|title=Sikorsky R-6 Doman Conversion (LZ-1A)|url=https://www.neam.org/ac-sikorsky-r6.php|website=New England Air Museum|publisher=The New England Air Museum}}</ref> Doman and his engineering team modified the R-6 by creating an entirely new rotor system which featured a unique gimbaled rotor hub that was subsequently used in all Doman helicopters.<ref name="two" /> After extensive successful flight testing of the modified Sikorsky R-6 (Doman LZ-1A), Doman's team designed and built, in a joint venture with the [[Curtiss-Wright]] Corp., an all-new Doman helicopter, the CW-40.<ref name="two" /> The CW-40 was followed a couple of years later by the [[Doman LZ-5]]/YH-31.<ref name="two" /> The many innovative features in this helicopter were soon covered by numerous Doman patents.<ref name="two" /> Meanwhile, after the departure of Mr. Frazier, the company was renamed Doman Helicopters, Inc. and moved to Danbury, CT.<ref name="two" /> Doman Helicopters continued for nearly 20 years, building and testing several helicopters and performing other related aircraft work to sustain the company while it attempted to establish itself as a major helicopter manufacturer.<ref name="fourteen" /> The [[Doman LZ-5]]/YH-31 helicopters were extensively tested by the company and by the U.S. Army and Navy.<ref name="fourteen" /> They received certification from the United States [[FAA]], and from the equivalent Canadian authority, for sale and commercial use, after passing the rigorous tests necessary for such approvals. [[Doman LZ-5]]/YH-31 helicopters toured the U.S. and were well received by potential customers, especially in the oil industry along the Gulf Coast. One even toured in France and Italy performing at the [[Paris Air Show]] in 1960.<ref name="two" />
Doman helicopters were a technical success but the company was unable to raise sufficient venture capital to set up an assembly line for mass production.<ref name="two" /> The company ceased operations in 1969 and was legally dissolved shortly thereafter.<ref name="two" />
[[File:Mod-2 Wind Turbine Cluster3.jpg|thumb|Mod-2 (2.5 MW wind turbine cluster in Goodnoe Hills, Washington)|300px]]
== Wind turbines and careers with other companies ==
In January 1970, Doman went to work for [[Boeing Vertol]] – Boeing's helicopter division in Philadelphia.<ref name="fourteen" /> There he continued his helicopter pioneering, working on U.S. Army funded research and patenting additional design improvements for helicopter speed increases and vibration reductions.<ref name="two" /> The [[1973 arab oil embargo]] triggered a great interest in wind energy at [[Boeing]] and numerous other companies.<ref name="six" /> While continuing his helicopter innovations, Doman began to conduct wind turbine research.<ref name="two" /> He adapted computer simulation models designed for helicopters to study wind turbines.<ref name="two" /> Doman and his team then built scale-model wind turbines to test them in a wind tunnel normally used for helicopters and airplanes.<ref name="two" /> Doman soon understood the similarities and key differences between wind turbines and helicopters.<ref name="two" /> Wind turbine designers with no experience in helicopters might not know the lessons-learned from the history of helicopter technology, but by the mid-1970s Doman had more than 30 years of such learning that was directly applicable to wind turbines.<ref name="two" /> [[Boeing]]'s MOD-2 with the Doman-conceived flexible design, two-bladed wind turbine with a teeter hinge, became a flagship achievement in a 7-year [[NASA]] managed wind energy program for the [[U.S. Department of Energy]] and the [[U.S. Department of the Interior]].<ref name="six" />
In January 1978, Doman returned to Connecticut as Chief Systems Engineer of the wind energy program at [[Hamilton Standard]] division of [[United Technologies]].<ref name="sixteen">{{cite web|title=Glidden Sweet Doman|url=https://www.neam.org/air-museum-news.php|website=American Helicopter Society|publisher=American Helicopter Society Internationsl|accessdate=June 9, 2013}}</ref> Drawing on Doman's extensive knowledge of rotor dynamics for both helicopters and wind turbines, [[United Technologies]] designed and built two of the largest wind turbines ever built up to that time (i.e. WTS-3, WTS-4).<ref name="six" /> Key features of those turbines, in addition to their size, were the use of only two blades (instead of three, which is more common) and the mounting of the blades on a teeter hinge hub.<ref name="two" /> This was analogous to Doman's use of the gimbaled hub on his helicopters, which had 4-bladed rotors.<ref name="two" /> One turbine (WTS-4) was installed and successfully tested at Medicine Bow, Wyoming, and the other (WTS-3) in Sweden.<ref name="four" /> The WTS-4 wind turbine held the world power output record for over 20 years.<ref name="seven" /> Throughout all the research studies and the testing of the actual turbines, there was rapid evolution in Doman's thinking on the best design concepts.<ref name="fourteen" /> However, when oil prices plummeted in the mid-1980s, United Technologies deemed the wind energy market to be uneconomical and halted the program.<ref name="two" /> [[File:WTS4 wind turbine.jpg|thumb|WTS-4 (4 MW wind turbine in Medecine Bow, Wyoming. This turbine held the world power output record for over 20 years)|300px]] The Italian government took notice of Doman's work, and in July 1987, when Doman retired from [[United Technologies]], he was hired by [[Aeritalia]] (the Italian manufacturer later known as [[Alenia Aeronautica|Alenia]]) and moved to Rome to head Italy's wind energy program.<ref name="two" /><ref name="seven" /><ref name="eight" /> In this program, Doman applied his latest thinking to a new machine, considerably improved over the WTS-4 and WTS-3 machines he had designed for installation in Wyoming and Sweden respectively.<ref name="four" /> Under Doman's leadership a team of Italian engineers designed the Gamma 60 turbine.<ref name="two" /><ref name="eight" /> The Gamma 60 was the world's first [[variable speed wind turbine]] with a teeter hinge.<ref name="one" /><ref name="eight" /><ref name="twenty">{{cite web|last1=Carlin|first1=P.W.|last2=Laxson|first2=A.S.|last3=Muljadi|first3=E.B.|title=The History and State of the Art of Variable-Speed Wind Turbine Technology|url=http://www.nrel.gov/docs/fy01osti/28607.Pdf|website=NREL|publisher=National Renewable Energy Laboratory|accessdate=February 1, 2001|ref=NREL/TP-500-28607}}</ref> Three Gamma 60 turbines were manufactured, and one was erected and successfully tested for 4 years on the Mediterranean island of Sardinia.<ref name="two" /><ref name="eight" /> There had been intentions to build many more Gamma 60 turbines, but Italian politics and a lack of urgency due to relatively low oil prices in the 1990s resulted in the program being cancelled.<ref name="two" />
In 2003, Doman and Italian nuclear mechanical engineer Silvestro Caruso formed a new company, Gamma Ventures Inc., and bought two unused turbines, the engineering drawings, and manufacturing rights from the Italian Gamma 60 project.<ref name="one" /><ref name="eight" /> In 2007, Gamma Ventures sold a turbine and manufacturing rights to the Dutch company – Blue H Technologies – that was adapting offshore oil platform technology to put wind turbines on floating platforms in deep water far from shore.<ref name="eight" /> Blue H Technologies installed the world's first floating offshore wind turbine in 2008 in the Southern Adriatic Sea with a two-bladed wind turbine.<ref name="eighteen">{{cite web|last1=Ebbert|first1=Stephanie|last2=Daley|first2=Beth|title=Proposal Could Calm Storm Over Wind Farm|url=http://archive.boston.com/lifestyle/green/articles/2008/03/15/proposal_could_calm_storm_over_wind_farm/|website=Boston Globe|publisher=The Boston Globe|accessdate=March 15, 2008}}</ref> After some revisions in corporate structures and plans, the Gamma rights were eventually transferred to a new company, Seawind, which is working on placing turbines with Gamma-type rotors on concrete offshore support structures, aiming to do so in numerous locations around the world.<ref name="eight" />
== The persistent innovator ==
Doman remained active right up to the end of his life in 2016; thoroughly engaged in business, technical strategies, and analysis toward superior wind turbine performance at less cost in the application of his novel rotor technologies.<ref name="eight" /> He was also an avid supporter of the [[New England Air Museum]] (in Windsor Locks, Connecticut), where two of his helicopters – the converted R-6 (Doman-LZ1A) and a [[Doman LZ-5]]/YH-31 – are on display.<ref name="thirteen" /><ref name="nineteen">{{cite book|last1=Jackson|first1=Paul|title=Jane's All the World's Aircraft|date=2016|publisher=Jane's Information Group|location=United Kingdom}}</ref>
Of the original 6 helicopter companies in the United States, Doman was the last company founder to pass away.<ref name="four" /> He was one of the few helicopter pioneers to have transferred rotor dynamics technology from helicopters to wind turbines.<ref name="five" />
A Norwegian project announced in February 2017, involving Dr. Techn. Olav Olsen and Seawind, aims to demonstrate the wind energy applications put forth by Glidden Doman, [[Anton Flettner]], and [[Kurt Hohenemser]] in harsh wind and sea conditions.<ref name="ten" /><ref>{{cite web|title=Seawind, Olav Olsen to Jointly Bring Forward 6.2 MW Demo Project|url=http://www.offshorewind.biz/2017/02/21/seawind-olav-olsen-to-jointly-bring-forward-6-2mw-demo-project/|website=offshoreWIND.biz}}</ref><ref name="eight" /> Doman worked through to his final days to ensure that one day wind-generated electricity will be produced in great quantities, much less expensively than now, using his advanced rotor technology concepts.<ref name="eight" />
== Photo gallery == <gallery> Image:Doman YH-31.jpg|United States Army - Doman LZ-5/YH-31 helicopter </gallery>
== Patents awarded by the United States Patent Office ==
# {{US patent|2,451,541}} – Dynamic balancer for rotor blades (filed on May 24, 1945, granted on October 19, 1948) # {{US patent|2,550,538}} – Directional and trim control for rotary wing aircraft (filed on August 9, 1946, granted on April 24, 1951) # {{US patent|2,648,387}} – Rotor head (filed on June 27, 1946, granted on August 11, 1953) # {{US patent|2,687,856}} – Gyroscopic control of sustaining rotors (filed on July 18, 1946, granted on August 31, 1954) # {{US patent|2,716,889}} – Method of determining and adjusting the aerodynamic pitching moment of a full-sized aerodynamic member and apparatus therefor (filed on November 25, 1952, granted on September 6, 1955) # {{US patent|2,810,443}} – Rotor head and swash plate means combination (filed on November 18, 1950, granted on October 22, 1957 # {{US patent|2,827,251}} – Aircraft frame with large side openings (filed on April 2, 1952, granted on March 18, 1958) # {{US patent|2,959,230}} – Mechanical directional and trim control for helicopters (filed on August 16, 1951, granted on November 8, 1960) # {{US patent|2,978,038}} – Swash plate operating mechanism and combination with swash plate (filed on Mar 11, 1958, granted on April 4, 1961) # {{US patent|3,007,530}} – [[Helicopter rotor]] head (filed on July 29, 1958, granted on November 7, 1961) # {{US patent|3,007,654}} – Rotor and blade for rotorcraft (filed on December 27, 1956, granted on November 7, 1961) # {{US patent|3,082,826}} – Rotor head with collective pitch control (filed on July 2, 1958, granted on March 26, 1963) # {{US patent|3,087,690}} – Rotor with two joints in drive shaft (filed on January 30, 1961, granted on April 30, 1963) # {{US patent|4,004,757}} – Oscillation damper for the hub of a rotorcraft rotor and its combination with a rotorcraft (filed on October 16, 1975, granted on January 25, 1977) # {{US patent|4,073,600}} – Damping mechanism for the rotor hub of a helicopter for ground resonance and waddle and its combination with the rotor (filed on June 14, 1976, granted on February 14, 1978) # {{US patent|4,329,117}} – Wind turbine with drive train disturbance isolation (filed on April 22, 1980, granted on May 11, 1982) # {{US patent|4,353,681}} – Wind turbine with yaw trimming (filed on May 19, 1980, granted on October 12, 1982) # {{US patent|4,515,525}} – Minimization of the effects of yaw oscillations in wind turbines (filed on November 8, 1982, granted on May 7, 1985) # {{US patent|4,695,736}} – [[Variable speed wind turbine]] (filed on November 18, 1985, granted on September 22, 1987)

{{ic|date=March 2017}}{{Use British (Oxford) English|date=January 2012}}
{{Electrical Wiring Sidebar}} '''IEC 60364''' ''Electrical Installations for Buildings'' is the [[International Electrotechnical Commission]]'s [[international standard]] on ''electrical installations of buildings''. This standard is an attempt to harmonize national wiring standards in an [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] standard and is published in the European Union by [[European Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization|CENELEC]] as "HD 60364". The latest versions of many European wiring regulations (e.g., [[BS 7671]] in the UK) follow the section structure of IEC 60364 very closely, but contain additional language to cater for historic national practice and to simplify field use and determination of compliance by electrical tradesmen and inspectors. National codes and site guides are meant to attain the common objectives of IEC 60364, and provide rules in a form that allows for guidance of persons installing and inspecting electrical systems.
The standard has several parts: * Part 1: Fundamental principles, assessment of general characteristics, definitions * Part 4: Protection for [[electrical safety|safety]] ** Section 41: Protection against [[electric shock]] ** Section 42: Protection against thermal effects ** Section 43: Protection against [[overcurrent]] ** Section 44: Protection against voltage disturbances and [[electromagnetic interference|electromagnetic disturbances]] * Part 5: Selection and erection of electrical equipment ** Section 51: Common rules ** Section 52: Wiring systems ** Section 53: Isolation, switching and control ** Section 54: [[Earthing arrangements]], protective conductors and protective bonding conductors ** Section 55: Other equipment (Note: Some national standards provide an individual document for each chapter of this section, i.e. 551 Low-voltage generating sets, 557 Auxiliary circuits, 559 Luminaires and lighting installations) ** Section 56: Safety services * Part 6: Verification * Part 7: Requirements for special installations or locations ** Section 701: Electrical installations in bathrooms ** Section 702: Swimming pools and other basins ** Section 703: Rooms and cabins containing sauna heaters ** Section 704: Construction and demolition site installations ** Section 705: Electrical installations of agricultural and horticultural premises ** Section 706: Restrictive conductive locations ** Section 708: Electrical installations in caravan parks and caravans ** Section 709: Marinas and pleasure craft ** Section 710: Medical locations ** Section 712: Solar photovoltaic (PV) power supply systems ** Section 713: Furniture ** Section 714: External lighting ** Section 715: [[extra-low voltage|Extra-low-voltage]] lighting installations ** Section 717: Mobile or transportable units ** Section 718: Communal facilities and workplaces ** Section 721: Electrical installations in caravans and motor caravans ** Section 722: Supplies for Electric Vehicles ** Section 729: Operating or maintenance gangways ** Section 740: Temporary electrical installations for structures, amusement devices and booths at fairgrounds, amusement parks and circuses ** Section 753: Heating cables and embedded heating systems ==See also== * [[Electrical wiring]] * [[Earthing system]]s * [[BS 7671]] * AS 3000
== External links == * [https://webstore.iec.ch/searchform&q=60364] All IEC 60364 parts and sections published by the [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20051126103456/http://www.nema.org/stds/electricalinstall.cfm] [[National Electrical Manufacturers Association|NEMA]] comparison of IEC 60364 with the US [[National Electrical Code (US)|NEC]] * [http://iaeimagazine.org/magazine/2001/01/16/how-the-iec-relates-to-north-america-particularly-iec-60364/ How the IEC relates to North America—particularly IEC 60364] * [http://www.electrical-installation.org/ WIKI-Electrical installation guide – According to IEC 60364], Schneider Electric, 2010. * [http://www.cablesizer.com Online Cable Sizing Tool to IEC 60364-5-52:2009] * {{IEC|60364}} {{List of IEC standards}} [[Category:Electric power distribution]] [[Category:IEC standards|#60364]]

'''JCO''' was a Japanese nuclear fuel cycle company established in October 1979 as a wholly owned subsidiary of [[Sumitomo Group|Sumitomo Metal Mining Co.]], Ltd. as Japan Nuclear Fuel Conversion Co. {{nihongo|日本核燃料コンバージョン|Nihon Kakunenryō Konbājon}}. As of 2000, stock capitalization was 1 billion USD.
== Timeline == * 1979 JCO was founded * 1980 Sumitomo Metal Mining Co., Ltd. conversion activities were handed over to JCO * 1983 The second factory building at [[Tōkai, Ibaraki|Tokaimura]] was completed * 1998 The name was changed to just JCO * 1999 [[Tokaimura nuclear accident]] * 2003 Uranium conversion activities stopped completely
== References == * [http://www.jaif.or.jp/english/news/1999/1209-1.html]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox power station | name = Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant | name_official = | image = RIAN archive 305005 Leningrad nuclear power plant.jpg | image_caption = Site of the Nuclear Power Plant Leningrad, including the construction site of the Nuclear Power Plant Leningrad II. | location_map = Russia Leningrad Oblast | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|59|50|50|N|29|02|37|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | country = [[Russia]] | location = [[Sosnovy Bor, Leningrad Oblast|Sosnovy Bor]], [[Leningrad Oblast]] | status = Operational | construction_began = 1 March 1970 (Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant I)
25 October 2008 (Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant II) | commissioned = 1 November 1974 (Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant I)
Unit II-1: October 29, 2018 | decommissioned = 2016 (planned, Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant I) | cost = | owner = [[Rosenergoatom]] | operator = | ps_units_operational = 4 × 925 MW
1 × 1085 MW | ps_units_uc = 1 × 1085 MW | ps_units_planned = 2 × 1085 MW | ps_units_decommissioned = | np_reactor_type = [[RBMK|RBMK-1000]] (Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant I)
[[VVER|VVER-1200/V491 (AES-2006)]] (Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant II) | np_reactor_supplier = [[Atomstroyexport]] | ps_electrical_capacity = 4785 | ps_annual_generation = 21,208 | ps_electrical_cap_fac = 60.5% | website = }} '''Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant''' ({{lang-ru|Ленинградская атомная электростанция; Ленинградская АЭС}} ({{Pronunciation|Ru-Ленинградская атомная электростанция.ogg}})) is a [[nuclear power plant]] located in the town of [[Sosnovy Bor, Leningrad Oblast|Sosnovy Bor]] in [[Russia|Russia's]] [[Leningrad Oblast]], on the southern shore of the [[Gulf of Finland]], some {{convert|70|km}} to the west of the city centre of [[Saint Petersburg]]. It consists of four nuclear reactors of the [[RBMK]]-1000 type. These reactors are similar to reactors No. 1 and 2 of the [[Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant]]. Two units of the [[VVER]]-1200 type are under construction at Power Plant II to replace the current RBMK reactors when they reach the end of their service lives. On 25 October 2008, Saint Petersburg [[Atomenergoprom|Atomenergoproekt]] began concreting the foundation plate of the reactor building of the Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant II, Unit 1. Cost of the project is estimated to be almost 70 billion [[Russian ruble]] (RUR).[http://www.rosatom.ru/en/news/12405_27.10.2008 Leningrad NPP-2: Concreting of the foundation plate of the reactor building of the 1st unit started; 27 October 2008]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}:[http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-Construction_starts_at_Leningrad_II-2710084.html Construction starts at Leningrad II; 27 October 2008]: A construction licence was issued on 22 July 2009.{{cite news | url = http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-Go_ahead_for_second_Leningrad_II_unit-2207095.html | publisher=World Nuclear News | date=22 July 2009 | title= Go-ahead for second Leningrad II unit | accessdate=26 July 2009}} From May 2012 to December 2013, Unit 1 was offline while repairs were made related to some deformed graphite moderator blocks.{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/RS-Restored-RBMK-back-on-line-0212137.html |title=Restored RBMK back on line |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=2 December 2013 |accessdate=3 December 2013}} == Reactor data == {| class="wikitable" |- ! style="width=21%; background:#CFCFCF;"| Unit[http://www.iaea.org/programmes/a2/ Power Reactor Information System] of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency|IAEA]]: [http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.powrea.htm?country=RU&sort=&sortlong=Alphabetic "Russian Federation: Nuclear Power Reactors"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226145334/http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.powrea.htm?country=RU&sort=&sortlong=Alphabetic |date=26 December 2008 }} ! style="width=22%; background:#CFCFCF;"| Reactor type ! style="width=08%; background:#CFCFCF;"| Net capacity
in [[Watt|MW]] ! style="width=08%; background:#CFCFCF;"| Gross capacity
in [[Watt|MW]] ! style="width=10%; background:#CFCFCF;"| Construction
started ! style="width=11%; background:#CFCFCF;"| Electricity
grid ! style="width=11%; background:#CFCFCF;"| Commercial
operation ! style="width=15%; background:#CFCFCF;"| Shutdown |- | Leningrad - 1 | [[RBMK]]-1000 | align="center" | 925 | align="center" | 1000 | align="left" | 1970-03-01 | align="left" | 1973-12-21 | align="left" | 1974-11-01 | align="left" | (2019) |- | Leningrad - 2 | [[RBMK]]-1000 | align="center" | 925 | align="center" | 1000 | align="left" | 1970-06-01 | align="left" | 1975-07-11 | align="left" | 1976-02-11 | align="left" | (2021) |- | Leningrad - 3 | [[RBMK]]-1000 | align="center" | 925 | align="center" | 1000 | align="left" | 1973-12-01 | align="left" | 1979-12-07 | align="left" | 1980-06-29 | align="left" | (2025) |- | Leningrad - 4 | [[RBMK]]-1000 | align="center" | 925 | align="center" | 1000 | align="left" | 1975-02-01 | align="left" | 1981-02-09 | align="left" | 1981-08-29 | align="left"| (2026) |- |- | Leningrad II - 1 | [[VVER#VVER-1200|VVER-1200]]/491 (AES-2006) | align="center" | 1085 | align="center" | 1199 | 2008-10-25 | 2018-03-09{{cite news |url=http://www.world-nuclear-news.org/NN-Leningrad-II-1-starts-pilot-operation-09031801.html |title=Leningrad II-1 starts pilot operation |publisher=World Nuclear News |date=9 March 2018 |accessdate=10 March 2018}} | 2018-10-29 | align="center" | - |- | Leningrad II - 2 | [[VVER#VVER-1200|VVER-1200]]/491 (AES-2006) | align="center" | 1085 | align="center" | 1199 | 2010-04-15[http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.prdeta.htm?country=RU&refno=164 Power Reactor Details Leningrad II-2 on the PRIS of the IAEA] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628235019/http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.prdeta.htm?country=RU&refno=164 |date=28 June 2011 }} | (2019https://nevnov.ru/435827-pervyj-energoblok-laes-2-nachnet-vyrabotku-energii-uzhe-v-mae-2017-goda) | (2020) | align="center" | - |- | Leningrad II - 3 | [[VVER#VVER-1200|VVER-1200]]/491 (AES-2006) | align="center" | 1085 | align="center" | 1199 | (Planned)[http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.prdeta.htm?country=RU&refno=165 Power Reactor Details Leningrad II-3 on the PRIS of the IAEA]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} | align="center" | ? | align="center" | ? | align="center" | ? |- | Leningrad II - 4 | [[VVER#VVER-1200|VVER-1200]]/491 (AES-2006) | align="center" | 1085 | align="center" | 1199 | (Planned)[http://www.iaea.org/cgi-bin/db.page.pl/pris.prdeta.htm?country=RU&refno=167 Power Reactor Details Leningrad II-4 on the PRIS of the IAEA]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} | align="center" | ? | align="center" | ? | align="center" | ? |- |} ==Incidents and accidents== [[Image:RIAN archive 894448 Leningradskaya nuclear power plant.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Fuel-handling assembly at Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant]] The first accident at the plant occurred shortly after the first unit came online. On 7 January 1975 a concrete tank containing radioactive gases from Unit 1 exploded; there were no reported accident victims or radiation releases.Nuclear Encyclopedia, chief editor A. A. Yaroshinskaya. - Moscow: the Charity Fund of Yaroshinskaya, 1996. - 656p.V. M. Kuznetsov, Russian Nuclear Power Engineering Yesterday, Today, Tomorrow. Opinion of independent expert. - Moscow: National press institute, 2000. - 288 p. Less than one month later, on 6 February 1975, the secondary cooling circuit of Unit 1 ruptured, releasing contaminated water into the environment. Three people were killed, and the accident was not reported in the media. On 28 November 1975 a fuel channel in Unit 1 suffered a loss of coolant, resulting in the degradation of a nuclear fuel assembly that led to a significant release of radiation lasting for one month. Immediately after the accident, the radiation level in Sosnovy Bor, {{convert|5|km}} from the affected power unit, was 600 mR/h; in total, 1.5 [[megacurie|MCi]] was released into the environment.[https://books.google.com/books?id=23b64xeqUnEC&pg=PA88 Controlling Technology By Stephen H. Unger, p. 88.] The exposed inhabitants of the Baltic region were not notified of the danger. The accident was not reported in the media. (Practically the same accident occurred in Unit 1 of the Chernobyl Power Station in 1982.)V. A. Melnikov, N. B. Malevannaya, Radiological Safety During the Operation of Nuclear Complex in Sosnovy Bor. - presentation at the international conference ENERGY. ECOLOGY. SAFETY, May 25–27, 1999, Sosnovy Bor. In July 1976 and again in September 1979, due to a poor safety culture, fire broke out in a concrete vault containing radioactive waste. Water used in extinguishing the fires was contaminated, leaked into the environment, and entered the water table. This was not reported in the media. On 28 December 1990, during refurbishment of Unit 1, it was noticed that the space between the fuel channels and the graphite stack (contaminated during the 1975 accident) had widened. The contaminated graphite was spilled, and the radiation levels in the space under the reactor increased. Radiation was detected 6 km away from the unit, but this was not reported in the media. On 3 December 1991, due to faulty equipment and lax safety rule compliance, 10 new fuel rods were dropped and damaged. The staff tried to conceal the accident from the management. In March 1992, an accident at the Sosnovy Bor nuclear plant leaked radioactive gases and [[iodine]] into the air through a ruptured fuel channel. This was the first accident at the station that was announced in the news media.Nuclear Energy Institute, [http://www.nei.org/corporatesite/media/filefolder/soviet_plant_source_book.pdf Source Book: Soviet-Designed Nuclear Power Plants in Russia, Ukraine, Lithuania, Armenia, the Czech Republic, the Slovak Republic, Hungary and Bulgaria] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20121211214430/http://www.nei.org/corporatesite/media/filefolder/soviet_plant_source_book.pdf |date=11 December 2012 }}, 5th edition, 1997, p. 141. On 27 August 2009, the third unit was stopped when a hole was found in the discharge header of a pump.[http://lennpp.rosenergoatom.ru/eng/press/news/article/?article-id=86CC234D-751F-4D89-8561-AB226345008D The third unit of Leningrad NPP has been stopped]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Rosenergoatom]], 28 August 2009 According to the automated radiation control system, the radiation situation at the plant and in its {{convert|30|km|adj=on}} monitoring zone was normal. The plant's management refuted rumors of an accident and stated that the third unit was stopped for a "short-term unscheduled maintenance", with a restart scheduled for 31 August 2009.[http://lennpp.rosenergoatom.ru/eng/press/news/article/?article-id=34559542-3942-4E44-B035-9C6D139D15CC Leningrad NPP refutes rumors about accident]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Rosenergoatom]], 28 August 2009 On 19 December 2015, unit 2 was stopped (scrammed) due to a broken steam pipe. No radioactively contaminated material was released. The situation inside Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant and the industrial area around the station has not changed and the radiation level remains within the limits of natural background values. ==Gallery== RIAN archive 305011 Leningrad nuclear power plant.jpg|Reactor hall of one of the RBMK units Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant 20JUL2010-4 (cropped).jpg|Construction site for Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant II, April 2010 ==See also== {{stack|{{Portal|Russia|Energy|Nuclear technology}}}} *[[Nuclear power in Russia]] == References == {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} *[http://www.lnpp.ru Leningrad NPP] – official website of the plant {{ru icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070912183108/http://lennpp.rosenergoatom.ru/eng/ Leningrad Nuclear Power Plant] – official website from operator {{en icon}}/{{ru icon}} *[http://www.times.spb.ru/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=27522 Ecologists Slam Nuclear Power Plant] {{Hidden Nuclear Power Plants in Russia}} [[Category:Nuclear power stations built in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations in Russia]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations using RBMK reactors]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations using VVER reactors]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations with reactors under construction]] [[Category:Nuclear power stations with proposed reactors]]
